newsitem.title: USA: Internet consumer privacy initiative gets backing.
newsitem.headline: Internet consumer privacy initiative gets backing.

text.p: A group of computer makers, software developers, telecommunications companies, retailers and publishers are backing an initiative to preserve consumer privacy and avoid government regulation on the Internet.

The initiative, called TRUSTe (formerly known as eTRUST), is a non-profit, industry-driven organization, based in Palo Alto, Calif. TRUSTe's goal is to promote electronic commerce by protecting consumer privacy and staving off regulation.
TRUSTe hopes to assure consumer privacy on the Internet by alerting consumers to the uses of their personal information through the use of "trustmarks" or logos, posted on Web sites.

TRUSTe's partners include AT&T Corp, International Business Machines Corp, Oracle Corp, Tandem Computers Inc, privately-held Wired Ventures, Netscape Communications Corp, Lands' End Inc, CyberCash Inc and many others.
TRUSTe was formed in July 1996 by the Electronic Frontier Foundation and some Internet companies and in October, 1996, it partnered with CommerceNet to implement its initiative.
On Tuesday, TRUSTe will announce the commercial availability of its program to use its branded trustmarks, which tell an individual how their information will be used.
Companies can license the trustmarks for a licensing fee, which ranges from $500 to $5,000, depending on the size of the company and the sensitivity of the information.

The trustmarks tell a consumer that the information they reveal online will not be used by the Web site they are visiting; that their data is collected only by the site's owner for its use; or that their data is collected and provided to third parties but only with the user's knowledge and consent.
"It's akin to a 'Good Housekeeping Seal' online," said Susan Scott, executive direcor of TRUSTe. "People are two to three times more likely to give information online if they know the use."

Scott also pointed to a study in March by the Boston Consulting Group, which said that concerns about privacy of personal information on the Internet is a consistent and significant concern for consumers online.
Web sites gather information about users through registration forms and commonly used software, known as "cookies," which track the online travels of individual users.

The Boston Consulting Group reported that in a survey, over 41 percent of respondents report leaving Web sites when asked to provide registration information over the Internet. In addition, another 27 percent provide false personal data.
The Boston Consulting Group estimated that as much as $6 billion in additional electronic commerce revenues could be gained by the year 2000, if privacy issues were addressed.
"We want (the trustmarks) to be ubiquitous throughout the 'Net," Scott said. "The consumer should have a choice."
TRUSTe said it will monitor its licensed Web site publishers to ensure the proper use of their trustmarks.
